content.raw: What led me to remove it is that there is no way I can get to that code path in the tests.  Generally I'm of the opinion that code should only be left in if there is a possibility to get to it (in a test, if nothing else), which was not the case here.  However, if there is impending work to be merged that depends on it, I can leave that in and just remove stopKp and stopKd (which we also can't currently reach with tests).  Let me know which way you want to go here.
content.html: What led me to remove it is that there is no way I can get to that code path in the tests. Generally I'm of the opinion that code should only be left in if there is a possibility to get to it (in a test, if nothing else), which was not the case here. However, if there is impending work to be merged that depends on it, I can leave that in and just remove stopKp and stopKd (which we also can't currently reach with tests). Let me know which way you want to go here.

content.raw:
Mostly to get rid of the boost::shared_ptr.  Since it wasn't being called anywhere, it seemed easier to remove it.  That being said, if we want to keep it for debugging, I can (eventually) convert it over along with the rest of the boost::shared_ptr that I need to do in this file.

As a sort of meta-question, do we need the code that is in the ifndef URDF_GE_0P3 code sections?  Getting rid of that code would also make my life easier.
content.html:
Mostly to get rid of the boost::shared_ptr. Since it wasn't being called anywhere, it seemed easier to remove it. That being said, if we want to keep it for debugging, I can (eventually) convert it over along with the rest of the boost::shared_ptr that I need to do in this file.

As a sort of meta-question, do we need the code that is in the ifndef URDF_GE_0P3 code sections? Getting rid of that code would also make my life easier.

content.raw:
I'm ok with removing functions which are hard to maintain and are not being used.

Humm good question about the URDF version. It [looks like](https://github.com/ros/urdfdom/releases) urdfdom 1.0 got rid of boost, so maybe we only want to support that version on sdf6. @scpeters ?

content.raw: Actually, that's a question I have.  Should we use nullptr always, even when comparing against raw pointers?
content.html: Actually, that's a question I have. Should we use nullptr always, even when comparing against raw pointers?

content.raw: My understanding is that the behavior between `NULL`  and `nullptr` is the same. The benefit is that we don't have to define `NULL`.
content.html: My understanding is that the behavior between NULL and nullptr is the same. The benefit is that we don't have to define NULL.

content.raw: OK, got it.  I'll keep that in mind for the future.

I just noticed this. It looks like we usually do using namespace sdf; on cc files. Not sure if this is something we enforce though.

$ grep -r "namespace sdf" src/
src/parser_urdf.cc:using namespace sdf;
src/Element.cc:using namespace sdf;
src/parser.cc:namespace sdf
src/SDFExtension.cc:using namespace sdf;
src/Console.cc:using namespace sdf;
src/Types.cc:namespace sdf
src/Converter.cc:using namespace sdf;
src/Param.cc:using namespace sdf;
src/SDF.cc:using namespace sdf;
src/Exception.cc:using namespace sdf;

content.raw: Oh, huh.  I was under the impression that "using namespace sdf" meant that you could refer to functions in namespace sdf without the sdf:: prefix, not that all of the functions would be put into namespace sdf.  Am I wrong about that?
content.html: Oh, huh. I was under the impression that "using namespace sdf" meant that you could refer to functions in namespace sdf without the sdf:: prefix, not that all of the functions would be put into namespace sdf. Am I wrong about that?

No, you're correct about that.

namespace sdf
{
  const int num = 1;
}

using namespace sdf;

const int num2 = 2;

int main()
{
  int r = 0;
  r += num;
  r += sdf::num;
  r += num2;
  //does not compile  'num2' is not a member of 'sdf'
  //r += sdf::num2;
  return r;
}

content.raw: I was also not sure about it, cool to see the proof.
content.html: I was also not sure about it, cool to see the proof.

content.raw: Actually, this points to a totally different problem.  If you look at parser_urdf.cc, there is no "namespace sdf" at the top of the file, which means that all of the functions in there are *not* in the sdf namespace.  I think they probably should be.  I'll prepare a patch (for a different PR) to fix that.
content.html: Actually, this points to a totally different problem. If you look at parser_urdf.cc, there is no "namespace sdf" at the top of the file, which means that all of the functions in there are not in the sdf namespace. I think they probably should be. I'll prepare a patch (for a different PR) to fix that.

content.html: Anything else we need to do here before approval/merge?

content.raw: This is looking good to me. I was just waiting on the `namespace sdf` style for `Types.cc`
content.html: This is looking good to me. I was just waiting on the namespace sdf style for Types.cc

content.raw: Ah, right, forgot about that one.  I don't care *too* much whether we do "std::string sdf::split" or "namespace sdf { std::string split}", though I prefer the latter.  It's too easy to forget to put the sdf:: when implementing a new function, and the failure mode is difficult to detect (the symbols are just in the wrong namespace, but otherwise everything works).  Thoughts?
content.html: Ah, right, forgot about that one. I don't care too much whether we do "std::string sdf::split" or "namespace sdf { std::string split}", though I prefer the latter. It's too easy to forget to put the sdf:: when implementing a new function, and the failure mode is difficult to detect (the symbols are just in the wrong namespace, but otherwise everything works). Thoughts?

content.raw:
I don't feel too strongly about this, I'm ok with wrapping within the namespace. 

We usually enforce indentation inside `{}`, but I'm ok with it the way it is now.
content.html:
I don't feel too strongly about this, I'm ok with wrapping within the namespace.

We usually enforce indentation inside {}, but I'm ok with it the way it is now.

content.raw: Actually, it looks like the only use of namespace { (before these PRs) is in parser.cc, where we don't indent the rest of the code.  I slightly prefer *not* indenting (as it doesn't waste vertical space), but I don't care all that much.
content.html: Actually, it looks like the only use of namespace { (before these PRs) is in parser.cc, where we don't indent the rest of the code. I slightly prefer not indenting (as it doesn't waste vertical space), but I don't care all that much.

content.raw:
wrapping the namespace works for me

also, it's pragmatic to not indent, so I'm also happy with how it is now
content.html:
wrapping the namespace works for me

also, it's pragmatic to not indent, so I'm also happy with how it is now
